subject: The War over the War....Congress defies the President; the President vows, "VETO."
body:

QUOTE
  OF THE DAY

"In heaven all the
  interesting people are missing." 
  - Friedrich Nietzsche 




DID YOU KNOW?

  The rosy periwinkle plant, found in Madagascar, is used to cure
  leukemia. 




TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWS

Here is an early preview
  of what Awe are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and
  Managing Editor, Katie Couric… 

  Hi everyone, 

  The U.S. Congress and President Bush are facing off in a historic showdown.
  Earlier today the Senate followed the House’s lead and passed
  legislation that would begin the withdrawal of U.S.
  troops from Iraq
  this fall – but the president has promised to veto it. Sharyl Attkisson will report from Washington, D.C., on
  the battle over Iraq.
  

  We’ll also show you some of the results of a new CBS News/New York Times poll, which includes
  Americans’ opinions about the troop withdrawal bill as well as the
  environment. For complete poll results this evening, go to CBSNews.com Click Here.
  

  Tonight is an important milestone in the race for 2008 – the first
  debate of the Democratic presidential candidates. Our new Senior Political
  Correspondent Jeff Greenfield
  will report that this South Carolina
  event will be a major test for the eight contenders, each of whom will only
  have a short time to make a lasting impression. 

China
  is still denying that the chemical melamine contaminated pet food and led to
  the deaths of dozens of pets. But Chinese officials have offered to cooperate
  with broader inspections of these products. Nancy
  Cordes will tell you what other foodstuffs enter the United States from China, and Barry Peterson will report on how those
  products are inspected. What they’ve found might surprise you. 

  Finally, we’ll have the story of a gospel choir found in an unexpected
  place. Steve Hartman will share
  their songs in this special Thursday edition of Assignment America. 

I hope you’ll join us
  tonight for these stories and an early look at Scott Pelley’s exclusive 60 Minutes interview with former CIA
  director George Tenet. 

  Thanks, 

Katie 

For more information on these stories,
  please click on the following links: 

Senate Passes Iraq Withdrawal Bill

Click
  Here 

Tenet: "Slam Dunk" Comment
  Misused 
Click
  Here 

And here’s a look at one of the
  stories we’re working on for Friday’s broadcast: 

  Tomorrow, we broadcast from Chicago - a town legendary for hard-knuckle power
  brokers, big personalities and broad shoulders. We'll give you a tour. All
  that and much more, Friday, on the CBS Evening News. 

  If you would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast,
  please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
evening@cbsnews.com
  




TONIGHT ON DAVID
  LETTERMAN

  Join Dave tonight on The
  Late Show with actor Steve Martin AND Dave Cota and A.J. the
  parakeet... Don't miss a Top Ten List presented by New York Yankees star
  Derek Jeter. Plus, musical guests Steve Martin, Tony Trischka and Bela Fleck!
  




FRIDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW

Harry Smith,
  Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Tracy Smith anchor THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave Price will bring us the weather. Russ Mitchell is off. 

Along with the top news of the day, we will
  also have the following stories: 

CSI BEHIND THE SCENES: Thursday
  night's episode of CSI features
  a very unusual murder... in a rather a-typical setting. Our own Julie Chen recently visited the set to
  ask the CSI cast about both.
  She went behind the scenes to get a taste of the action first hand. And she
  learned that the cast is not the only group with challenging roles. It was a
  challenge for the creative wizards at CSI
  to make a believable model of character Lorenzo "Happy" Morales, a
  boxer who takes an arrow through the neck and gets shot with a hypodermic
  filled with snake venom. We'll go behind the scenes Friday morning. 

HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL IN HARLEM: A JON
  FRANKEL DOCUMENTARY: High school football has long been a part of Americana: the
  rivalries, families gathering under the lights, cheerleaders flipping on the
  field. But it hasn't always been an easy road, especially for some frustrated
  guys from Harlem, New York. Jon Frankel is the director of a
  new documentary, Hellfighters A Season in
  Harlem, which follows a unique and inspiring team. The documentary
  premieres Friday night at the Tribeca Film Festival in New York City. Friday morning, Jon Frankel
  will join us with a sneak peek at his inspirational film. 

SURVIVOR CASTOFF: The
  competition heats up on Survivor!
  Stranded in Fiji,
  the competition grows fierce for the remaining Survivors competing against
  one another for the million-dollar prize. In one of the most shocking Tribal
  Councils ever, alliances crumble and a hidden Immunity idol is brought into
  play. Was it a successful gambit, or was it all for naught? And who will be
  voted off the island? Friday morning, the latest castoff will join us. 

WEDDING IN A WEEK: WEDDING RECAP:
  This week has been tons of fun! Before our lucky couple ties the knot, let's
  take a quick look at how this Wedding in a
  Week came together. Master event planner Colin Cowie will recap our Wedding in a Week -- elaborating on all
  the elements that went into creating this ultimate wedding for couple Lisa
  Mayo and Stephen Wilfong. 

WEDDING IN A WEEK: THE CEREMONY:
  Finally the moment we've been waiting for. It's time for our Wedding in a Week couple to walk down
  the aisle, and they'll be doing so to the music of Chrisette Michelle --
  singing her new song Golden.
  The celebration continues as Lisa and Stephen exchange their vows on our
  plaza! 

  If you would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast,
  please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
earlyshow@cbs.com
  



 
SATURDAY ON 48 HOURS
 
Here's a note from Bill Lagattuta on Saturday's 48 Hours Mystery, Murder in the Fast Lane: 

  "The story of Mickey Thompson is the story of a genuine American
  hero--the man who at one time was the fastest man on earth. He was a
  down-to-earth racing icon, a tough businessman, an innovator and he was
  married to the love of his life, Trudy. It all came to a horrible end almost
  twenty years ago when Mickey and Trudy were gunned down, execution style, in
  the driveway of their Los Angeles
  area home. I remember covering this story as a young news reporter, and it's
  fitting for me to be present at the final chapter. 

  From the beginning, the focus of the investigation was Mickey Thompson's
  colorful business partner, Mike Goodwin. But there was no physical evidence
  to tie him to the crimes. For the past two decades, through a series of
  fascinating twists and turns, detectives and Thompson's hard-driving sister
  Colleen have been pursuing Goodwin, hoping his flamboyant personality and his
  big mouth would be his undoing. In our program this week, we will take you
  step by step through this fascinating case... and you'll be able to watch
  what many considered the surprise ending in court. Murder in the Fast Lane was an amazing story for me to
  live, and to report. I hope you will join us on Saturday night." 

  - Bill Lagattuta 

(48 Hours Mystery
  airs Saturday at 10pmET/9CT) 

  If you would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast,
  please click on the following address and e-mail us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com
  



 
SUNDAY ON 60 MINUTES
 
AT THE CENTER OF THE STORM: Ex-CIA
  Director George Tenet appears in his first network television interview to
  talk about what it was like as the head of the security agency during 9/11,
  the war on terror and the hunt for Osama bin Laden. He also says that the
  Bush Administration acted dishonorably when it used his famous "slam
  dunk" remark about WMD in Iraq to ruin his reputation and
  his career. 

ARMED AND DANGEROUS: Should
  someone who has been deemed an imminent danger to himself, like Virginia Tech
  shooter Seung Hui Cho, be allowed to own a gun? The law says no, but advocates
  for the mentally ill say yes. Steve Kroft
  reports.
